text: 1 Mostly darkness in the small apartment, a few table lamps illuminating a comfortable, crowded well worn space. On o shelf, souvenirs from a past life: a framed NY Times Best Seller list from 1980 with Kilgallen by Lee Israel highlighted in the number 15 spot. Five or six copies of book, and a similar number of Miss Tallulah Bankhead (als Lee) and many more of Estee Lauder by Lee Israel line a shelf. It’s a bit of a trophy case. Across the room, a well worn cat tree sits in the corner, piles of New Yorkers, and LEE ISREAL, around 50 and not trying very hard, is asleep in her clothes on the couch. Blossom Dearie record spins on the record player, a cat snoozes in her lap. Both snore. An alarm beeps on Lee’s c digital watch. Finally, she rouses. She looks down at her watch which reads 10pm, and stops the alarm. She moves to the kitchen, responding slightly to the musi We imagine she may be getting ready for bed. She puts her plate in the sink, and returns. She downs her water from table and puts the glass into her purse. She takes a bott of scotch and also puts it into her purse. She turns off light, but then the front door opens, hall-light pouring and we see Lee exit. The door slams shut. 2

Nondescript cubicles and the nondescript people who are working in them. It is the graveyard shift and the YOUNG EMPLOYEES are proofreading and black-lining law documents The large room is eerily silent save for the scratching o pencils on paper and the sound of ICE CLINKING in a glass Lee is working as well, drinking a scotch on the rocks. S swirls it around absentmindedly as she works without enthusiasm. TWO YOUNG WOMEN pass by her cubicle.
(whispering) Fucking kill me if I’m doing this at her age. Lee hears, and waits til she can’t see them.
I’ll kill you now if you ask nicely. (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 2. 2 Embarrassed giggles. Swirling her glass of scotch, Lee wo Someone shouts from another cubicle, head barely visible
You know we’re not allowed to eat or drink in here!
(after a beat) Yeah. Lee ignores them. The first cubical worker tries to peer to Lee. Hello? Fascist. Alcoholic.
Some laughter. Lee goes back to her work, tries to concentrate. She can’t.
(beat) Why do you give a crap?
Because the sound of the ice is driving me insane.
Me too! It’s making me crazy!
Oh, fuck off. She drinks, making as much ice noise as possible.
What did you say?
I believe I said fuck off. A tall MAN, 30, appears at her cubicle.
I’m your boss. Pack up. (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 3. 2
I’m almost through with this document. Now.
He takes the document and other papers from her desk and gestures for her to get up.

(quietly) Please, I need this job. He ignores her, watching as she puts her things into her canvas bag (including her glass and bottle of scotch). He walks behind her, ushering her out. The young people in the cubicles watch with amusement as goes. Breaking into loose applause. 3

Straight from the job, Lee puts her groceries up on the counter - cereal, peanut butter, a can of cat food. On th small black and white TV a program with garishly wealthy characters is playing. The CASHIER, 60s Asian woman, is skeptical.
(she knows her) How much have you got?
(fishing in her pocket) Enough.
Show me first. Lee counts out her disappointing amount of cash.
Okay, just this. She separates the cereal and cat food and pays for them.
Put this other stuff back! Lee walks out. 3
4 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 4. INT. LEE’S UPPER WEST SIDE APARTMENT - MORNING 4 Lee opens the cat food and places it in front of her cat JERSEY, who’s not interested.

Since when did you become picky. She puts the cereal on the counter and walks through her cluttered apartment. Peeling paint, way too much stuff an years of stacked up New Yorker magazines. The small one bedroom apartment hasn’t been updated in at least 20 year paint is chipping, furniture is worn and scratched by multiple cats, even the light bulbs need dusting. But you tell it was once a well-loved little box of a home. The dining table is covered with papers and coffee cups a empty wine bottles, leaving little room for the manual typewriter and old computer. 5 INT. LEE’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS 5 A few dead flies lie on her pillow. Disgusted, she brushe them off and curls up to sleep in her clothes. 6 INT. LEE’S BATHROOM - EARLY EVENING 6 Broken shower tiles, an old moldy curtain. In the medicin cabinet mirror, Lee smooths down her hair and applies lipstick. She notices the litter box in the corner is in unused, pristine condition. 7
8 Lee approaches the 1 train entrance at 86th street and descends the stairs. 9
9 Shivering from the cold, she treks down the New York stre 10
10 Lee has entered a noisy, stylish party. Forty or so festi members of the New York literary world cheerfully enjoy cocktails and conversation. (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 5. 10 She notices a COAT GUY taking jackets, but she walks past in search of the bar. Her host MARJORIE, 70 years old and sophisticated, sees h
Well, this is a surprise.
You invited me, did you not?
You didn’t reply.
(ignoring that) A coat check? At my party we threw coats on a bed.
Nice to see you too, Lee.
(beat) You never call me back. I’ve got some new ideas.
This is why you’re here?
You don’t know what I’ve been doing just to get by.
Well, you’re here now. Try to enjoy yourself, Lee. Marjorie excuses herself.
The bar as Lee gratefully finds it. She gets her drink and turns, walking through the crowd. overhears a conversation between TOM CLANCY, 40 famous writer, and a crowd of eager followers. (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 6. 10
I don’t subscribe to the notion of writers block.
You never experience it?

Writers block is a term invented by the writing community to justify their laziness. The crowd laughs. TOM CLANCY (CONT’D) My success is nothing more than that I have the dedication and stamina to sit and get the work done. It’s simple.
Having Ronald Reagan talking about you doesn’t hurt. Well sure.
Lee passes the conversation, unimpressed.
(walking by) Jackass.
Who’s that? Tom Clancy shrugs, and Lee wanders, not knowing anybody. People hustle by her, having a good time. SEVERAL YOUNG GUESTS are huddled together and Lee eavesdr
You have to read them. As an American.
Well, sure. Lee looks around, landing on SEVERAL OLDER PEOPLE sitting couches, not talking to anybody. They line the perimeter of the room, sipping their drinks They’re old wallflowers.
11 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 7.

11 Lee walks down the hall that’s decorated with framed photographs, book jackets, signed letters - it’s Marjorie professional Memory Lane. She glances up to assess TWO FRAMED BOOK JACKETS. One is KILLGALLEN, by Lee Israel and the other is MISS TALLULAH BANKHEAD also by Lee. Unhappy with their placement, she quickly swaps them out a couple of frames that are closer to her eye line. 12 INT. MARJORIE’S POWDER ROOM - EVENING 12 Lee is snooping in the cabinet and finds a drawer filled almost finished toilet paper rolls. A dozen of them at le Weird. She grabs the fullest one and drops it into her large bag She takes the bar of guest soap as well. 13 INT. MARJORIE’S APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS 13 She snakes her way through the party and makes it to the front door just as Marjorie stops her.
That was quick. Did you get properly fed?
This week. Will you take my call?
(condescendingly) Sure. We’ll see.
I have fascinating projects! I’m working on a lot of ideas - I just need my agent to call me back.
(laughing to herself) Well, nobody needs a new biography on Fanny Brice, Lee. We may disagree on what is considered fascinating. She starts to walk away. MARJORIE (CONT’D) Good night Lee. (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 8. 13
(stopping her) Why do you have mostly used toilet paper rolls in the drawer of your bathroom? What?
I just can’t figure it out.
You went through my bathroom cabinets?
Just tell me. I’m curious.
So that guests can have a full roll.
That’s batshit, Marjorie.
(to herself) You would know... At the coat check Lee points to a very sophisticated, lon wool coat.
Yeah, I lost the ticket, but that’s the one. The coat check guy doesn’t flinch, but hands it to her.

Have a good night, ma’am. Lee takes the beautiful coat with a smirk. 14 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - LATER THAT NIGHT 14 Lee sits on her couch, drinking scotch, with her new coat slung over the couch. On the TV Lillian Hellman’s black a white film THE LITTLE FOXES plays. It’s a scene Lee knows heart, but that doesn’t stop her from enjoying every fram (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 9. 14 Bette Davis is snuffing candles whilst quibbling with her brothers Charles Dingle and Carl Benton Reid. Lee loves t

(along with the TV) There are lots of things to consider. After all, they are first cousins. (then answering herself) Well that isn’t unusual. Our grandmother and grandfather were first cousins. (back again) Yes and look at us! She removes some appetizers from her purse, shoves one in her mouth and offers one to the cat. LEE (CONT’D) Jersey, here girl! The cat wanders over but doesn’t eat them. Lee is concern 15 INT. VETERINARIAN’S OFFICE - DAY 15 Lee is at the counter, holding a cat carrier and talking the assistant RACHEL.
You still have a balance, Ms. Israel.
But there’s something wrong with her. She’s very old.
I’m sorry. The doctor told me to get at least half the balance before we do any tests.
Don’t you take a Hippocratic oath or something? Don’t you have to do something?
You owe us eighty two dollars. Lee pulls some bills out of her back pocket.
Look, I’ve got - fourteen dollars. I’m sorry.
(CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 Lee walks out of the office.
Unbelievable. 9A. 15
16 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 10.
16 Lee enters, wearing her stolen coat, carrying two heavy b of books. 17
17 GLEN, a 30 year old nerd and the used book buyer, glances briefly at Lee’s pile of old books on the counter. There CUSTOMERS waiting behind her.
Just these. That’s it? here.
I schlepped them all the way
(dismissive) I’ll give you two dollars. I don’t want the others. He goes to the cash register to pay her.
Come on, man. I don’t need much. I just don’t want to carry them around. (beat) I’ve got a sick cat and I need the money. Please.
(rude) I told you I don’t want the others. There’s people waiting.
You don’t have to be so disrespectful. You’ve actually carried my books here. Glen turns to her, amused.
And you are?
(irritated) I’m Lee Israel. (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 11. 17

Oh, Ms. Israel. I do recognize you now. In fact, your latest work is right over there! He points to a table of books with a sign “75 percent off Displayed is several copies of Estee Lauder: Behind the Magic.
You rude little ape. What have you ever written? She turns to leave.

Hey, get your garbage off my counter! He pushes her books away from him and some fall onto the floor. She scoops them up protectively. 18 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT BUILDING - ENTRYWAY - DAY 18 Lee enters her building, and upon seeing Andrei, 50s Romanian, tries to turn around and go right back out, but calls out.
Hi, Andrei.
I knock on your door but you never answer. We’re going on three months.
No, I know. I’m really sorry about that. I’m working on it.
I don’t want to have to call the management.
Can you cut me a little slack? It’s been a rough patch. I just lost my job. I think it was ageism.
Can’t you write another book? (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 12. 18
Last one was a bit of a calamity.
I like you, you’ve been here longer than I have, and you’ve always been kind to my mother. Just get it to me soon.

I will. Absolutely. Thank you. Andrei start to walk away. LEE (CONT’D) But hey, in the meantime, do you think you could get an exterminator in my apartment? I’ve got an untenable fly situation. 19 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 19 Lee drinks coffee and reads the newspaper. She glances briefly at a framed letter on her wall. Reluctantly, she to it, takes it from the wall, examining it. It’s a frame letter from Kathryn Hepburn. Lee sighs. She knows what sh has to do, but she doesn’t like it. She takes the letter off the wall. 20
20 Lee walks down the street and enters a beautiful shop wit First Edition Books and Framed Prints in the window. 21
21 Inside the dark and cozy store, Lee stands before ANNA, 4 as she reads the Katherine Hepburn letter.

(reading) Lee, Today was to have been the Esquire shoot with Spence. Difficult days, these. Thank you for your sympathy and understanding. Ever Yours, Kate. P.S. Forgive the splotches. All tears lately. (then) Such a lovely apology. (beat) (MORE) (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 13. 21
This is very special. Why would you part with it?
(beat) Clutter, you know. I’m not a very sentimental gal.
(appreciatively) Handwritten even. You’re the Lee Israel?
Oh, Jesus. Is there another?
I’ve read your biographies! Have you?
You’re a wonderful writer.
Thank you. Can you remind my publisher?
Working on anything new?
Besides my tan? Anna smiles.
So, how did this letter come about?
I wrote for some magazines a while ago it was going to be Spencer Tracy - but then he died.
Well, her letters usually have the intimacy of a phone book, but this one is really nice. (beat) How does one seventy five sound?
Sounds terrific. (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 14. 21
If you ever are feeling sentimental, you can come visit it! 22 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 22 She takes out a can of cat food and opens it.

I got you the good stuff, you old snob! She puts it in a bowl on the floor, but the cat doesn’t m LEE (CONT’D) It’s the fancy feast. 23 EXT. JULIUS’ BAR - AFTERNOON 23 Jack enters. 24 INT. JULIUS’ BAR - AFTERNOON 24 Lee sits drinking, headphones on. Someone takes the seat near her but she doesn’t look up. about 50, queer and charming. He’s JACK HOCK. He gets the attention of CRAIG, the bartender.
Good afternoon, darling. Can I have a beer?
Hi Jack, handsome, I don’t know, can you? Jack quickly pulls out a twenty and puts it on the bar. C goes to get the beer. Jack recognizes Lee.

Lee Israel!? Lee turns and then recoils, never liking to have to talk anyone. She struggles to pull out a name, taking off her headphones reluctantly. JACK (CONT’D) It’s Jack Hock! And the last time I saw you we were both pleasantly pissed at a horrible book party. Am I right? (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 15. 24
It’s flooding back to me. You were friends with Julia JACK Steinberg. She’s not an agent anymore. She died.
She did? So young.
Or maybe she didn’t die. Maybe she just moved to the suburbs - I always confuse those two. No, that’s right. She got married and had twins.
Better to have died.
Indeed. (excited) I just came from having my teeth bleached. How do they look? He smiles wide. His teeth are almost too white.
Why would you do that?
Teeth are a dead give-a-way. Okay.
(beat) Let me buy you a drink. Even though you’re the posh writer. He signals to the bartender.
Well, thank you. I’m trying to remember that party you mentioned. Something keeps flashing in my mind. Something that happened but I can’t put my finger on it.
Bad shrimp? (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 16. 24
Jack Hock, you said?
That’s me. The renegade, the rebel. Jack Hock. Big cock. He flashes his smile. Lee thinks.
It will come back to me.
I’ll try not to be offended. We’ve been shit faced drunk together more than once, but...
My memory is shot. Don’t take it personally. Craig drops a drink for Lee.
How has life been treating you?
I can actually boast that I’ve been banned from Crosby Street Booksellers.
What did you do?
I did nothing. People are idiots.

(beat) I’m banned from Duane Reade. (beat) All of them. She glares at him. JACK (CONT’D) I have a little shoplifting problem. Lee moves her bag to other side of her stool. JACK (CONT’D) All in the past. But for some reason I have a very memorable mug. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 17. 24 JACK (CONT’D) Now I have to take a bus just to buy shampoo or aspirin or something. (beat) I’m joking. Duane Reade’s not the only rodeo in town.
(dawning on her) You pissed in the closet!
I did what?

I remember now. Nobody could stop talking about the handsome English gentlemanJACK Why thank youLEE Who was so shit-faced he mistook the coat closet for the can. You ruined thousands of dollars worth of furs. Jack is caught, unsure how this will go over. Well, I-
But Lee loves this story.
Those old ninnies didn’t know what had hit them! Their disgusting furs, all covered with piss. Dogs were following them home. I laughed about that for weeks. Jack starts laughing along with Lee.
Well I’m glad somebody found it amusing. (then) A few folks stopped talking to me after that night. Fuck ‘em. Cheers.
(CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 18. 24 They cheers.
So, do you work, Jack Hock?

This and that. Mostly that. (beat) I happen to have some very nice coke, if you’re interested. She looks at him, appalled. JACK (CONT’D) Jesus, it’s not like I have it all the time. A boy’s gotta do what a boy’s gotta do. (beat) Anyways, who are you to judge? It’s four in the afternoon and you’re drunk.
I’m hardly drunk. And it’s not “anyways,” it’s just “anyway.”
Well keep drinking then. The day is young. 25 EXT. JULIUS’ BAR - NIGHT They come out and walk. 25
26 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 19.
26 Lee and Jack ride the subway.
You get out the next stop?
(nodding) 79th. You?
I’ll get out there. That works. A beat. JACK (CONT’D) I think I saw you in Zabar’s once. You were shouting at someone.
Terrible customer service. Been going there for years.
They have really good bread. They both nod comfortably.
EXT. GLEN’S APARTMENT - NIGHT
A MAN (Glen) comes out of an apartment building with an adorable puppy and attaches it to a leash.
Come on, Coco. You’re such a good girl. Lee stares at him and taps Jack.
That’s the guy - the guy from Crosby Street Booksellers! No!
They watch as he affectionately kisses his dog.
Who knew he was human.
You got a paper and pen? (CONTINUED)
Why? Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 19A.
Lee reaches into her bag and gives him what he needs. He into the vestibule of the guy’s building and looks to be copying names off the buzzer list. 27
27 They approach Lee’s building.
This is me.
Nice place?
It used to be nicer. (beat) And you? (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 20. 27
(vague) Oh - a couple blocks up. She reaches out to shake his hand.
Good-bye Jack. This was not unpleasant.
I’ll see you tomorrow? You shall.

She goes into the building. 28 INT. LEE’S LOBBY - CONTINUOUS 28 She goes inside and after a moment, turns to see him thro the glass door, standing there, looking kind of lost. Aft moment, he walks off. 29
30 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 21.
30 Lee, dressed neatly, smooths down her hair and knocks on door. LISA, 20s, answers. She seems put off by Lee’s appearance let’s her in. Lisa leads Lee inside.
The employment agency said this was an executive assistant position.
Your name’s Lee, right?
Ms. Israel, if you don’t mind. MS. WHITMAN, a wealthy, intimidating woman in her 30s eme from upstairs.
We do first names here. This is Lisa. I’m Ms. Whitman. They shake. 31 INT. MS. WHITMAN’S TOWNHOUSE - DAY 31 In the enormous living room, Lee is holding a beige color bra.

Go to Bendels on Fifth. There’s two kinds, but both are under wire, 34B. One has lace on the sides and the other is plain. Get them in Apricot. It’s new. If you can’t find them ask Celeste, she’ll help you. Buy four each. Bring that one with you just to make sure.
You know Town shop is just across 86th?
Doesn’t matter. And don’t take a cab. Take the bus or better yet, take the subway. It’s faster. Lisa enters. (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 21A. 31 MS. WHITMAN (CONT’D) Lisa, fill Lee in on some basics please. (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 Hi. 22. 31
So, what is your job?
That doesn’t concern you. She does everything you don’t do. Of course. 32

32 Lee is sitting on the subway with a Bendels bag in her la She’s reading a book about Fanny Brice. A LITTLE GIRL (7 years old) is standing in front of her, staring at her. Lee tries to ignore her but eventually lo up at the kid. They stare at each other.
Are you a man?

Are you a gargoyle? The STARTLED MOTHER yanks at her daughter’s arm and pulls away. Lee goes back to her book. 33 INT. MS. WHITMAN’S APARTMENT - CORRIDOR - SAME DAY 33 Lisa is showing Lee how to record things in a log book.
So you have to account for how you spend your time each day. If you make a phone call for her, write it here. If you make a phone call for yourself, write it there.
Is this for real?
What do you mean?
Everything I do, I write down? Yes.
(CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 23. 33
Going to the bathroom? Yes.
(beat) You get paid at the end of each day, in cash. Lovely.
Lisa goes to a drawer in the corridor and takes out two twenty dollar bills.
(off Lee’s disappointed face) Ms. Whitman pays what she thinks is fair, considering it’s under the table.

location: STREET OUTSIDE OF CROSBY STREET BOOKSELLERS

text: Across the street, Lee stands in a phone booth as Jack ha her the sheet of paper from the night before, with the li of names from the buzzer. She puts in a quarter and dials As Lee speaks, they watch the front of the store.

(in thick Long Island accent) Hello, I’m looking for the tall guy, the book buyer, Glen. Oh, hello, thank god! This is Lillian Schuster from the fourth floor. There’s an emergency! The building’s on fire. We’re all outside! Oh my god it’s horrible!... no, they’re not letting us back in! You better come over and get your dog! I see flames coming out of your window right now! I think I hear the poor thing squealing! They watch as Glen frantically trips out of the store and runs up the street. They crack up, gratified.
That was very enjoyable.
Thoroughly. (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 23A.
You do such a good voice! Lee reaches into her pocket.

I’ve got no jingle in my jeans. You got a token? Put out, Jack looks through his change. 34 INT. VETERINARIAN’S OFFICE - WAITING ROOM - DAY 34 Lee sits with other PET OWNERS in the waiting room. A YOU GIRL is with her DOG.
(to a Lady with cat carrier) She’s so cute!
Unless she’s shredding the side of my sofa.
Oh, I guess that’s not good.
Cats. Not for me. Lee leans over and pets the Old Man’s OLD DOG.
He’s a good boy, isn’t he? The best.
He looks sick. (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 24. 34
Just needs a shot. He could use a bath but he doesn’t like it.
Pearl here isn’t going to like getting declawed but it’s
It’s cruel to de-claw your cat. Excuse me?
It’s like walking on glass for the rest of their lives.
I haven’t heard that.
Well, tell that to my ten thousand dollar Ligne Roset.
I would, except it’s an object. The receptionist, Rachel, calls out.
Jersey Israel? Lee gets up and goes to the counter. RACHEL (CONT’D) Hi, Ms. Israel. Are you’re able to pay for the tests?
That’s why I’m here. (beat) You shouldn’t de-claw.
Oh, it’s harmless. Really. Lee takes a deep breath. 35 INT. MS. WHITMAN’S BEDROOM - ANOTHER DAY 35 Lee is writing a letter by hand for Ms. Whitman while she dictates from her bed. (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 25. 35
The event was clearly a success and I couldn’t have succeeded without you. Your help and advice have been very generous and LEE Are you sure you want to use success two times? Excuse me?
(reading) ‘Clearly a success and succeeded.’
I’m sorry, did I ask you for advice?
I just thought MS. WHITMAN I have a Masters degree in English, Lee.
And I’m a published author, Ms. Whitman. Whitman sighs deeply, thinking she’s being mocked.
Can we continue, please? Of course.

Now I lost my train of thought. 36 INT. MS. WHITMAN’S LIBRARY - LATER THAT DAY 36 Lee is at the large bookshelf organizing and dusting the books. Surprised, she finds her own book MISS TALLULAH BANKHEAD, and pulls it out. Lisa enters the room.
Ms. Whitman doesn’t like anyone touching the books. (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 26. 36
How can I possibly organize and clean them if I cannot touch them?
I mean, you know what I mean. Ms. Whitman enters.
Lee, I need you to balance Natalie’s checkbook.
Your teenager.
Yes, I’ve opened an account for her. She needs to learn responsibility.
By me balancing her checkbook? Ms. Whitman looks at her, coldly considering her.
If you want to borrow a book, simply ask before handling it.
I mentioned that I was a published author. This is my book. Ms. Whitman inhales.
I get the sense you’re not very happy here. I’m giddy.
You’re sarcastic and impolite. (beat, leaving) You’ll be paid for your time here.
If you can call it pay. 37
Lisa hands Lee two twenties and then slams the door. 37
38 Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 27.

38 Ms. Whitman is holding the Tallulah Bankhead book, lookin with shock at Lee’s photo on the back. 39 INT. MS. WHITMAN’S APARTMENT - CORRIDOR - CONTINUOUS 39 Lisa silently reads Lee’s log, mouth agape. 1:45 - 1:48. Took a dump and scratched my cunt. 3:22 - 3:26. Got fired. 3:27-3:28 Took another dump. Forgot to flush. Oops. 40 INT. JULIUS’ BAR - AFTERNOON 40 Lee enters the bar, looks around, and sees Jack a few sto away. She sits away from him.
I rang you and you didn’t ring me back. Should I take it personally?
Why wouldn’t you?
I’d never get out of bed.
And lucky for me, you did. She’s somewhat entertained by him, in spite of herself.
I’m coming to sit next to you because I’m not very good at social cues. He moves next to her and Lee speaks to Craig, the bartend
Scotch, water, Craig. And I’ll buy his next one.
You got it.
Oh, things are looking up!
Got shit-canned again. (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 28. 40
That is exactly the reason I don’t get a job. (beat) You’re a successful writer. Aren’t you writing a book?
On Fanny Brice. Who?
Just the greatest vaudeville comedian of her time. You sure you’re a fag?
Lee crosses into the large library. 41

41 The table is covered with articles and books. Lee is taki notes on a pad. She separates some papers and finds TWO TYPED LETTERS SIG BY FANNY BRICE. Her eyes widen. She looks around - to let someone know the letters don’t belong here - and then she changes her mind. She reads them with a kind of secret thrill. She glances around the room, relieved that no one is look her way. Quickly, she drops the letters into her canvas b 42
42 Anna greets Lee as she enters the shop.
Oh, hi Lee. Nice to see you again.
You as well.
How’ve you been? (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 29. 42

Well, I’ve discovered that my cousin Sydney was in possession of this delightful bonne bouche. I thought you might be interested in it. She hands her one of the Fanny Brice letters, protected i plastic.
Fanny Brice. One of my favorites.
(finally!) I’ve been working on a new biography on her.
What a funny coincidence then, that your cousin had this! (beat) Well, she’s much more your style than Estee Lauder.
Right? Thank you.
Didn’t she say “Wrong is for other people.”? I love that.
(impressed) She did. Anna smiles and looks to the letter. LEE (CONT’D) Well, what do you think?
I believe I could sell this. (beat) I could offer you seventy five. Oh.
(disappointed)
I could pay more for better content. It’s a bit bland, is all. (CONTINUED)

Oh, I can assure you. It’s the real thing. No one can write like Ms. Parker could. Not before and not since. (CONTINUED)
Final Shooting Draft 3/13/17 120. 161 The bittersweet compliment is music to her ears.

Well, that might be out of my price range, but thank you very much. 162 INT. LEE’S APARTMENT - DAY 162 Lee sits at her old typewriter (the one she already owned and writes. LEE’S VOICE My dear sir, I offer my droopy salutations from the Great Beyond. I understand that you’re selling my personal letters to the tune of nearly two grand. To think poor Lee Israel received a tiny fraction of that sum when she sold them to someone, who then sold them to you. 163

163 We see the man through the front window, reading this let He looks into the distance, considering. Disturbed, he mo to the shop window. LEE’S VOICE I dearly hope this letter will not affect the selling price of your valuable artifact. As I most famously muttered mere moments after my cremation: “Darling, excuse my dust.” Yours, Dorothy Parker.
